1. Prevent employees, contractors, and/or visitors from entering area until leak is isolated or repaired.

1. Prevent employees, contractors, and/or visitors from entering area until leak is isolated or repaired.

4. Ensure proper PPE is donned during leak repair (respirator, gloves, etc.)

Process Hazard Analysis 
Entergy has conducted a process hazard analysis (PHA) for the SCR process at the Lewis Creek plant.  The PHA includes the following items:

* Hazards of the process
* Identification of previous, potentially catastrophic incidents
* Engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards
* Consequence of failure of controls
* Siting
* Human factors
* Qualitative evaluation of health and safety impacts of control failure

Entergy will review the results of the PHA as documented by the PHA review team.  Entergy will update the PHA every 5 years and will keep documentation of PHAs and actions for the life of the process.  

Operating Procedures
Entergy has prepared written operating procedures that give workers clear instruction for safely conducting activities involving SCR process.  In some cases, standardized procedures developed by industry groups or provided in industry-specific risk management program guidance are used as the basis for an individual operating procedure.  Entergy will update the operating procedures whenever there is a major change in process and before startup of the changed process.

Entergy has developed operating procedures required by EPA under the Risk Management Plan for the SCR process.

Training

Entergy Lewis Creek Plant RMP Executive Summary

GENERAL
Entergy is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for Entergy workers, the public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, Entergy has established systems to ensure safe operation of the facility.  One part of this system is the Risk Management Program that complies with the Environmental Protection Agency's regulation 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements.  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) describing the risk management program at Entergy's Lewis Creek plant.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMP requirements and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at Entergy's Lewis Creek plant near Willis, Texas.

The Entergy Lewis Creek Plant is a fossil-fueled steam, electric generating facility burning natural gas.  The Lewis Creek Plant consists of two generating units with a combined capacity of 530,000 kilowatts.  Unit 1 initial operation was November 3, 1970 at 4:15 p.m., and Unit 2 initial operation was March 24, 1971 at 6:35 p.m.  Units 1 and 2 were designed to use natural gas as the primary fuel with No. 2 fuel oil as a standby, which is not in use any longer.  The Lewis Creek Plant Standard Industry Classification (SIC) code is 4911.

The plant is located in Montgomery County, two miles west of Willis, Texas.  From Interstate 45-North, take Longstreet Exit (No. 95).  Turn left on Longstreet Road and travel two miles to the Lewis Creek Plant and enter through the main gate.  The area is rural with open pastures, rolling hills and forest areas.  Within 5 miles of the plant there are small subdivisions located on Lake Conroe and residential areas in the western side of Willis.  Immediately next to the plant is a reservoir that belongs to Entergy and has restrictions on public access.

Why ammonia is considered a toxic chemical?
Anhydrous ammonia (pure, undiluted ammonia) used for industrial purposes is a very powerful chemical compared to the diluted ammonia found in household cleaning products.  Ammonia is only dangerous to the public if it is released to the air, and even then it would have to be released in a large enough quantity to drift beyond the property line of the Lewis Creek Plant.  It is important to realize that the likelihood of a release of anhydrous ammonia is very slim and the release of quantities large enough to cause long-term health effects is very unlikely.  Well-trained personnel using safe operating procedures at the Lewis Creek Plant will assure safe handling of the anhydrous ammonia.


Regulatory Programs
The Lewis Creek plant is subject to regulation by federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under the Risk Management Program and by the federal Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA).  Both of these agencies regulate the SCR process installed at the Lewis Creek Plant.  Entergy has designed the SCR process to have built-in safety features such as automatic shutoffs, flow controls, ammonia detectors, and other equipment that is designed to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  The personnel who operate the process are trained in proper operation and how to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  Entergy will implement the procedures outlined in its Risk Management Plan (RMP) to assure that the public and the environment are protected.  

Entergy has developed this Risk Management Plan to reduce the potential of accidental releases of ammonia by performing a hazard assessment, developing a prevention program, and conducting emergency response planning
 
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response
Entergy implements reasonable controls to prevent unforeseeable releases of hazardous substances

.  In the event of a significant accidental release, our trained personnel respond to control and contain such releases as appropriate.  Each situation is evaluated individually and appropriate measures are taken to protect the employees and the community. Entergy, first responders, and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) have established a program to warn the community if an accident occurs that could threaten the community.  

Regulated Substances
Entergy handles several substances regulated by the RMP rule but ammonia is the only one present in sufficient quantities to be covered by the RMP rule.  The information below indicates the process as defined by the rule and the regulated substance.

Regulated Process:  This covered process consists of a storage tank containing a maximum of 150,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The liquefied ammonia is loaded into this tank from a tank truck/rail car.  This tank is supplied with redundant relief valves.  This operation is monitored by an unloading technician.  This ammonia is then transferred from the storage tank to the Selective Catalytic Reduction units on each boiler.

Five Year Accident History 
The five-year accident history includes all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage off site.  There have been no recordable accidental releases at the Lewis Creek Plant associated with the use of ammonia or any other chemical subject to the EPA Risk Management Program.  


Offsite Consequence Analysis
Entergy performed an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) to estimate the potential for an accidental release of ammonia to affect the public or the environment.  The OCA consists of evaluating both worst-case scenarios and alternative release scenarios. Entergy does not expect the events that would cause a worst case scenario to eve

r occur because of the nature of the process and the provisions for safe operation that are used by Entergy.  Alternative release scenarios help the LEPC improve the community response plan.  In accordance with EPA RMP rule guidance of March 2004, this executive summary will not include any OCA data.
 

Prevention Program Overview
The prevention programs developed by Entergy for the Lewis Creek Plant include a compilation of specific safety information, written operating procedures, and training of employees in those procedures.  The prevention program includes implementation of procedures for maintaining the mechanical integrity of the process equipment, for conducting internal compliance audits, and for investigation of every incident which results in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of ammonia.  The prevention program section of the RMP includes process safety information on the SCR process and specific information on ammonia.  This section of the RMP also discusses the employee training program for the Lewis Creek plant.  

The main prevention program component for the SCR processes is a comprehensive process hazard analysis (PHA), which consists of a rigorous, step-by-step examination of processes, equipment, and procedures to identify each point at which an accidental release could occur.   

The following is a summary of the SCR process accident prevention program at the Lewis Creek plant. Because the SCR process at the Lewis Creek plant regulated by the EPA RMP rule is also subject to the Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system that will be in place to implement the accident prevention program. 

Process Safety Information
Entergy keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters

ergy personnel will inspect and test process equipment based on written procedures.  The procedures will be based on recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices for inspection and testing.  

Entergy will correct equipment deficiencies found during inspections, tests, or by other methods before further use of the process equipment or whenever necessary to ensure safety and will establish a QA program for new construction and equipment, newly installed equipment, maintenance materials, and spare parts and equipment.

Management of Change 
Entergy has developed procedures to address management of change.  The procedure deals with the following issues:

* Technical basis for the change 
* Impact on safety and health
* Modifications to operating procedures
* Necessary time period for the change
* Authorization requirements for proposed change

The purpose of the management of change procedure is to assure that changes to the process, chemicals used, equipment, and maintenance or operating procedures are reviewed and approved prior to any changes being made.

Incident Investigation 
Entergy procedures for Lewis Creek Plant ensure that investigations of any incident related to the SCR process is initiated promptly.  Investigations will begin within 48 hours of an incident.  The procedures include a process to establish a knowledgeable investigation team.  

The team will gather the facts, analyze the event, and develop the how and why of what went wrong.   At least one team member will have knowledge of the SCR process.  Entergy will consider adding workers in the process area where the incident occurred as part of the team.   The team will summarize the investigation in a report that will identify the factors contributing to the incident.  Entergy will establish a system to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations.  Entergy will document the resolutions and corrective actions. Pre-startup Safety Reviews 
Entergy has developed and implemented a procedure to conduct a pre-startup safety review for the new stationary sources or modified stationary sources when the modification is significant enough to require a change in safety information under the management of change element.  This procedure was developed for the startup of the SCR process.  The pre-startup safety review procedure insures that procedures for safety, operating, maintenance, and emergencies are adequate and in place.

Mechanical Integrity  
Entergy has established and implemented a program to assure the mechanical integrity of pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. 

Entergy has establish and implemented written procedures to maintain the integrity of process equipment.  Entergy's process maintenance personnel assigned to the SCR process are trained on an overview of the process and its hazards.  Ent

Training Requirements
Each employee before being involved in operating a newly assigned process will be trained in an overview of the process and in the operating procedures as specified in 40 CFR 68.69 Operating procedures. The training includes emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.  The following parts of the operation procedures are addressed by the training.  

(a) Operating procedures for the process including the following:

(1) Steps for each operating phase or after an emergency shutdown. 
(2) Operating limits  
(3) Safety and health considerations 
(4) Safety systems and their functions 
    
At least every three years, these employees will be provided refresher training. 

A method has been developed to determine that each operator has received and understood the training.  The method may be a test, a practical demonstration or simulation, and/or interview.  A record of the date of the training and the method used to verify that the training was understood by the employee is kept by the facility.  These records will be available to an inspector during inspection of the facility.  

Hazmat employee training will include the following:

(1) General awareness/familiarization training
(2) Function-specific training
(3) Safety training
       (i) Emergency response information
       (ii) Measures to protect the employee from the hazards associated with hazardous materials
       (iii) Methods and procedures for avoiding accidents 
       
A record of current training, inclusive of the preceding three years, in accordance with this section will be created and retained by Entergy for as long as that employee is employed by Entergy as a hazmat employee and for 90 days thereafter.

Compliance Audits 
Entergy will conduct an audit of the process to evaluate compliance with the prevention program requirements at least once every three years.  The audit will be conducted using an audit procedure developed by Entergy for the Lewis Creek Plant.  The audit team will consist of personnel selected for their knowledge of the RMP requirements and knowledge of the process.  The team will consist of at least one person who is knowledgeable in the SCR process and will consist mostly of persons who are independent from the operations and environmental activities at the Lewis Creek plant.  

In addition to the accident prevention program activities, Entergy has safety features on the SCR process to quickly detect a release, to contain or control a release, and to reduce the consequences of a release.

Emergency Response
Entergy has in place an Integrated Response Plan that describes, in one plan, all the emergency response actions required at the Lewis Creek Plant.  The emergency response requirements under the Risk Management Program are being incorporated into the Integrated Response Plan.  Entergy will work with the local emergency response personnel to assure that everyone involved will be ready to respond when needed.   

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Since the Lewis Creek Plant is subject to the RMP regulations, the facility has implemented the prevention programs as outlined in the RMP and adheres to the RMP/Process Safety Management procedures.  Also, issues that are identified in the Process Hazard Analysis will be addressed with corrective action in a timely manner.

Energy's Pickens Plant, a liquefied natural gas facility, is located adjacent to and due north of the plant.  The power plant and the LNG facility are the only industrial facilities in the immediate area.  

The burning of fuels such as natural gas or fuel oil causes the emission of nitrogen oxides.  Nitrogen oxide emissions from many sources combine with hydrocarbons in the air to form ozone.  The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has determined that by reducing the emission of nitrogen oxides in the Houston area, there will be a reduction in the ozone levels.  The TCEQ has required Entergy to install pollution controls at the Lewis Creek Plant.  Based on this requirement, Entergy has installed equipment called Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) units that are used to reduce the nitrogen oxide emissions from the Lewis Creek plant's two boilers.  

Since, the SCR process uses anhydrous ammonia, the Lewis Creek plant is subject to the federal Risk Management Program.  The Risk Management program is designed to promote safe operation of industrial processes.  The program is intended to protect the public and the environment.  Entergy is committed to protecting the safety of the public and its employees.  

Entergy will have as a priority the safe use of ammonia at the plant.  Entergy's program will reduce the chance of an accidental release of ammonia.  This program includes the following:

1. Equipment and Processes designed for safe operation
2. Personnel trained in the safe use of ammonia and operation of the process
3. Cooperation with local officials including fire and police departments, and 
4. Communication with local citizens
